test_cases.description: There is stillness, and an air of drowsiness. We see the pastry chef, Wainwright, two veterinarians, Bashir Ahmed, and some others. Closer to Edison, behind Harriet, are Tesla, Marconi, Bell, and Watson. Edison spins to Harriet, his mouth trembling, squinting into her ears. His tired ears glance at her; he glances slowly to Bell. Edison glances at Tesla, who just blinks tersely. Edison glances down, then raises his nose to Bell. The calm brings sand to their ears and chuckles to their noses. Tesla crouches to Edison. Edison places his elbow out to him, and Tesla grabs it. Another tick of a clock. He is not fully rejuvenated, but well on the way. We get a wide-angle image now and see that Cartier-Bresson is snapping one of her cherished topics again. She is enjoying the chatter, as is Harriet, who is twirling softly to one side of the field, and Marconi, who sits folded-knee like Edison on the ground. Watson is scribbling on maps with him but laughs at this. And she clicks him again, as he passes the book back to Clara. Julia is perching next to Clara, inspecting a collection of sketches of Edison, obviously Cartier-Bresson's. Julia suddenly raises a sketch up for Edison to gaze at. It's one of him, knees wide, mouth round. Edison taps her on the nose with his toe as she giggles. But Cartier-Bresson has glanced from Marconi to Edison, clearly rattled by the inference in Marconi's phrases. Julia has gestured to the rusty bell dangling from his overalls. He peeks at it, and stretches his toes out. The two boys assist him. She is capturing his standing-up and leaning on the two boys. He strolls away, but has a sudden memory and spins to Marconi. Marconi blinks soberly and Edison strides for the gate, Cartier-Bresson trailing with him. He has bypassed her, he's in the archway. We see the throng at the edge of the meadow, where the shadow of the evening is beginning to dim. He spins, jesting in his slightly whimsical manner with children. She clicks him against the arch -- the throng churning remotely, waiting -- then she raises her tripod. He spins; the last phrases have uncovered the grin on his ears; they have a pleasurable hint of humor about them. Cartier-Bresson gazes as he strolls into the meadow toward the throng in the distance. She spins to Harriet. Harriet assents solemnly. Cartier-Bresson glares at her, then spins to gaze out at him. Harriet blinks, but she keeps on twirling and tries to sound whimsically indifferent but her inherent passion keeps bursting through in her tone and on her ears. Edison is strolling forward in the throng, one knee resting on Clara, the other on Julia.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

Gandhi exchanges meaningful glances with Mirabehn, Nehru, and Azad. Nehru bends, and Gandhi extends his hand, which Nehru grasps firmly, signaling Gandhi's partial recovery. Bourke-White captures the scene, enjoying the atmosphere along with Mirabehn, who spins wool, and Patel, who sits nearby. Abha shows Gandhi a playful picture of himself, and he taps her head with affection. Gandhi checks his watch, gestures to Abha and Manu for assistance, and Bourke-White photographs the moment. As Gandhi moves towards the garden's crowd, he shares a light moment with Bourke-White, but the truth in his words brings a somber tone. Bourke-White watches Gandhi approach the crowd, reflecting with Mirabehn, who masks her emotions with a veneer of cynicism. Gandhi proceeds into the crowd, supported by Manu and Abha.
